node.title: Silver Ferns to travel to England
node.description: The Silver Ferns will travel to London in January for the International Quad Series as a part of their buildup to the Commonwealth Games.

node.title: Helen Clark chides international community's pandemic response
node.description: Former prime minister Helen Clark says the wheels are in motion on structural responses to the pandemic preparedness but progress is slow. Audio

node.title: Kāinga Ora policy forces thousands in payouts to terrorised neighbours
node.description: Kāinga Ora's 'sustaining tenancies' policy has cost the taxpayer thousands of dollars in payouts.

node.title: Ohio jury holds major pharmacies accountable for opioid crisis
node.description: Lake and Trumbull counties blamed three chain pharmacies for flood of pills that caused hundreds of overdose deaths, attorneys said.

node.title: Tips for navigating holiday travel
node.description: Experts anticipate even more headaches at airports this holiday season, as record numbers of travelers take to the skies.

node.title: Michigan Hospital Chiefs Say State Can't Wait 'to Correct Course' Amid Winter COVID Surge
node.description: "The vast majority of patients in the ICU and on ventilators are unvaccinated," said chief medical officers representing hospitals in Michigan.

node.title: 'All Is Not Too Well' Viral TikTok Captures Argument Between Couple Over Taylor Swift Song
node.description: "I just want a man to protect me the way he would the reputation of a man he has never met," a commenter said.

node.title: Stewart Rhodes Said Oath Keepers Were in 'More Deadly' Situation Than American Revolution
node.description: Stewart Rhodes, the founder of the Oath Keepers, also accused former President Donald Trump of "complaining" on January 6 but not taking action.

node.title: Staff Shortages Force New York Hospital to Close Emergency Room as Winter COVID Surge Looms
node.description: New York is now reporting a daily average of more than 6,000 new cases, up 56 percent in the last 14 days.

node.title: Brian Laundrie, sole suspect in Gabby Petito's homicide, died by suicide, lawyer confirms
node.description: Brian Laundrie, the sole suspect in the strangulation of his girlfriend Gabby Petito during their US road trip, took his own life, according to a lawyer for his family .

node.title: WA politicians told to get vaccinated by cut-off date, or face being locked out of parliament
node.description: Politicians find themselves in a similar boat as ordinary West Australian workers as they, too, are warned they will be locked out of their workplace if they fail to meet a COVID-19 vaccination deadline.

node.title: Boy drowns in backyard pool in Adelaide's north
node.description: A seven-year-old boy drowns in a swimming pool in Para Hills West.

node.title: Jetstar pilot remains in custody as police work to solve missing campers case
node.description: Police arrest and interview 55-year-old pilot Greg Lynn and examine his 4WD for forensic evidence as they investigate the disappearance of Russell Hill and Carol Clay in Victoria's remote high country in March last year.

node.title: Best Buy Says Theft is a Reason for Profit Decline as Organized Robberies Increase in U.S.
node.description: Retailers have seen an increased amount of thefts, with several smash-and-grabs just in the past week. Companies like Best Buy say it's affecting their profits.

node.title: Foodbank charity feeding 74,000 hungry SA children a month
node.description: Some 135,000 South Australians are relying on the Foodbank charity for groceries every month as rising living costs continue to eat away at household food budgets.

node.title: Nineteen Covid-19 deaths announced as Victoria closes in on 90% vaccination rate
node.description: Nineteen people have died of Covid-19 in Victoria - the second highest daily death total since the current outbreak began in the state.

node.title: In Venezuela’s Flawed Vote, Maduro Shows One Way to Retain Power
node.description: European observers said the elections were neither free nor fair. They showed how President Nicolás Maduro’s government, however unpopular, can win by excluding and splitting opponents.

node.title: U.S. Bomber Flights Prompt Russia, China to Announce Military Cooperation
node.description: The Russian Defense Ministry said that the nations "expressed a shared interest in stepping up strategic military exercises and joint patrols."

node.title: Alabama, Wisconsin Among Football Teams in Player Safety Study Using Mouthguard Sensors
node.description: Ten NFL teams have used the sensor mouthguards for years, but a league official said they also wanted to study research schools with strong football programs.

node.title: St Peter's sexual abuse apology likely to trigger further claims
node.description: The revelations of historical abuse at a prominent Waikato boarding school is expected to trigger more claims from former students.

node.title: Watch Live: Waukesha parade crash suspect makes first court appearance
node.description: Five people died and 48 were injured when Brooks allegedly drove his SUV into a Wisconsin holiday parade Sunday.

node.title: Zena Stein, 99, Dies; Researcher Championed Women’s Health
node.description: She studied the impact of AIDS on women and explored the effects of famine and poverty on health with an “unwavering commitment to social justice.”

node.title: With cases surging, officials in the Buffalo area are the first in New York to bring back a mask mandate.
node.description: Cases have doubled in Erie County over four weeks, prompting the return of a mask requirement for stores, restaurants, bars, salons, and other public indoor spaces.

node.title: Kāinga Ora reconsidering evictions policy, minister says
node.description: Minister Poto Williams says a case in Whangārei is now before the justice system - and while evictions remain a 'last resort', the government will not accept adding to homelessness.

node.title: Proud Boys, Oath Keepers subpoenaed by January 6 committee
node.description: Chairman Bennie Thompson said the groups and their leaders "have relevant information about how violence erupted at the Capitol and the preparation leading up to this violent attack."

node.title: With a Second ATP Finals Win, Alexander Zverev Proves He Is Rising
node.description: This year gave the 24-year-old German star six singles titles, Olympic gold, an ATP Finals trophy, but also an ongoing tour investigation into allegations of physical abuse against a former girlfriend.

node.title: Bill Virdon, Quiet Manager of Four M.L.B. Teams, Dies at 90
node.description: As a player, mainly for the Pirates, he was an outstanding center fielder and hit a catalytic ground ball in the 1960 World Series against the Yankees.

node.title: Dollar Tree will raise prices to $1.25 by the end of April.
node.description: The price increases come as dollar stores have been struggling with a slowdown in sales and shrinking profits.

node.title: Jury in Arbery Case to Decide Reasonableness of Shooting in Self-Defense, Citizen's Arrest
node.description: "'Reasonableness' seems like a simple word, but it plays the most significant role in determining this case," former federal prosecutor Michael McAuliffe said.

node.title: Texas Man Tells Beto O'Rourke to 'Get the Hell Out' During Campaign Stop
node.description: "I'm in your grill telling you don't come back. We don't want you here," the man told O'Rourke in a video that has gone viral on Twitter.

node.title: 'Unite the Right' Organizers Must Pay $25M to 9 Injured During Charlottesville Rally
node.description: Some of the country's most well-known white nationalists were accused of organizing the violence the lawsuit said.

node.title: 'Vaccination surges' lift three remote NT communities to 100 per cent first-dose rates
node.description: As the Northern Territory battles its first remote COVID-19 outbreak, authorities say the "vaccination surges" they are undertaking across communities that are under threat are the difference between life and death.

node.title: The Arbery family and friends say they are anxious but hopeful of guilty verdicts.
node.description: Marcus Arbery, Ahmaud Arbery’s father, said that what he had seen in the courtroom was “devastating.”

node.title: Rural Health Care Providers Get $7.5 Billion in Relief Funds
node.description: The money will help offset the increased expenses and revenue losses that rural hospitals and clinics have experienced during the pandemic.

node.title: Over $760K Raised for Waukesha Parade Victims in Less Than 24 Hours
node.description: Some victims are raising funds for their recovery and arrangements on the fundraising site GoFundMe.

node.title: Tips for enjoying a healthy Thanksgiving meal
node.description: "It's really about making choices, not about cheating," registered dietitian Laura Cipullo told CBSN.

node.title: U.S. Man Released By China Was Not Part of Prisoner Exchange, Official Says
node.description: A U.S. official said it may have looked like a prisoner exchange, but instead was a product of continuing efforts for Beijing to live up to obligations.

node.title: Iraqi Infant Buried Without His Parents Present Latest Death in Poland-Belarus Standoff
node.description: An unborn Iraqi child was buried in Poland's largest cemetery Tuesday, the latest in the unknown death toll of the migrant crisis along the border.

node.title: 3-Year-Old Missing After Deadly Explosion Levels Houses in Michigan Neighborhood
node.description: About 20 houses were damaged from the explosion, which was felt miles away. It is unknown what caused the blast but an investigation is underway.

node.title: Federal Jury Finds CVS, Walgreens, Walmart Pharmacies Contributed to Opioid Crisis
node.description: The crisis has killed half a million Americans over the past two decades, but this was the first time pharmacy companies defended their role in court.

node.title: These chimney stacks were demolished at Lithgow more than 20 years ago. Today more will follow, marking the end of an era
node.description: NSW coal station workers pay homage to the history of one of the state's first fossil fuel power generators, set to be demolished with today to make way for a renewable energy hub.

node.title: What is the Strategic Petroleum Reserve?
node.description: The Biden administration is tapping into the nation's oil stockpile in hopes of lowering fuel costs for the holidays.

node.title: As Federal Disaster Aid Languishes, Private Lenders Are Filling the Gap
node.description: A new program allows Morgan Stanley to front money for disaster repairs and then get paid back, with interest, by taxpayers.

node.title: House Panel Investigating Capitol Attack Subpoenas Proud Boys and Oath Keepers
node.description: Investigators believe the militia or paramilitary groups have information about the deadly siege on Jan. 6.

node.title: Netherlands Weighs Restrictions for Unvaccinated as New COVID Cases Hit Record High
node.description: The proposals, which will be debated next week, aim to protect "unvaccinated people against infection, illness and hospital admission in high-risk locations."

node.title: Roger Stone, Alex Jones Say They'll Likely Plead the Fifth in Response to Jan. 6 Subpoenas
node.description: The two Trump allies have been asked to give testimony by December 17 and December 18, respectively.

node.title: Woodside's $16 billion Scarborough the last of the mega projects as tide turns on gas
node.description: Woodside's Scarborough project has found itself thrust to the front line in the war against fossil fuels by conservationists and those concerned about rising emissions.

node.title: Australia and Indonesia keep talking about a 'green economy’ — but what does that look like?
node.description: The two countries have been giving speeches and issuing statements about green economies for at least five years. What has been happening and where is it heading?

node.title: Jury awards $25 million in Charlottesville "Unite the Right" civil case
node.description: Plaintiffs sought millions in damages from white nationalist and neo-Nazi leaders who organized the two-day rally that left one dead and scores injured.

node.title: Deaf football team makes history
node.description: For the first time in nearly 60 years, California School for the Deaf could watch their varsity football team win the division championship.

node.title: These are the stores that will be closed on Thanksgiving
node.description: More retailers are giving workers the holiday off, although a handful will be open for early Black Friday shopping.

node.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Forced Cinderella to Scrub the Stage Floor’
node.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

node.title: Jon Batiste on His 11 Grammy Nominations: ‘I’m So Over the Moon’
node.description: The jazz pianist and bandleader on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” received the most nominations for the 2022 awards. Music “connects us to the sacred, the divine,” he said.

node.title: My Book Was Censored in China. Now It’s Blacklisted — in Texas
node.description: Andrew Solomon never expected his books to come under threat in America. But as he writes in this essay, attacks on books are on the rise here, and one of his is under investigation by a state legislature.

node.title: She Ran a Bronx Homeless Shelter. Here’s What She Spent Millions On.
node.description: A shelter operator admitted using money from the city to cover personal expenses, including shopping sprees at Neiman Marcus and Manolo Blahnik.

node.title: Jury Finds Rally Organizers Responsible for Charlottesville Violence
node.description: Jurors found the main organizers of the deadly right-wing rally in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017 liable under state law, awarding more than $25 million in damages, but deadlocked on federal conspiracy charges.

node.title: Pentagon Says 'U.S. Forces Will Remain in Iraq' Despite Militia Warning for Dec. 31
node.description: "U.S. forces will remain in Iraq, at the invitation of the Government of Iraq, in an advising, assisting, and intelligence-sharing role to support the Iraqi Security Forces in the campaign to defeat ISIS," a Pentagon spokesperson told Newsweek.

node.title: DOJ Sues to Stop U.S. Sugar From Buying Rival, Cites 'Already Cozy Sugar Industry'
node.description: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit to stop U.S. Sugar from acquiring one of its biggest competitors, an example of recent antitrust crackdowns.

node.title: Michael Strahan Latest Celeb Slated for Space Trip: Which Noted Stars Are Next
node.description: Other celebrities, including Angelina Jolie, Leonardo DiCaprio and James Cameron, have reportedly all purchased tickets to fly on upcoming space flights.

node.title: Conviction of Lesser Charges in Arbery Case Could Open Path for Jury to Find Felony Murder
node.description: "If the lesser-included offenses are still felonies, then it could support a felony murder conviction," defense attorney Richard Lawson told Newsweek.

node.title: 103-Year-Old Describes Experience Picking Cotton in American South in Viral Video
node.description: Madie Scott worked as a sharecropper first in her home state of Georgia and then in Florida, where she believed she could make more money.

node.title: Singer MAY-A on being nominated for an ARIA Award at age 20
node.description: Her five top songs have been streamed more than 18 million times.

node.title: Are bosses liable for compo if you catch COVID-19 at work?
node.description: Businesses could face workers' compensation claims from staff if they can prove they caught COVID-19 in the workplace, lawyers say.

node.title: Foreign stem cells saved Shelley's life, but doctors say they should be available at home
node.description: Stem cells made the difference for Shelley Garvie, but experts say Australia is a long way behind where it needs to be in finding donors for the treatment and are calling for reform.

node.title: Explosions tear through Serbian munitions factory, killing two and injuring 16
node.description: The blasts reportedly shattered windows in nearby homes and could be heard in the centre of the Serbian capital 15 kilometres away.

node.title: Tourism industry says clarity on COVID-19 test funding a 'Christmas gift for consumers'
node.description: Tourism operators are rejoicing after federal Health Minister Greg Hunt confirmed PCR tests required for anyone travelling in to and out of Queensland, would be funded in a 50–50 arrangement between the federal and state governments.

node.title: After caring for her mother for 12 years, Leonora realised she would have to start working again at 74
node.description: Leonora Brown cared for her ailing mother for 12 years — and after her death, the 74-year-old realised she would have to return to workforce.

node.title: 'There's a buzz in the air': Five Christmas gift ideas that will make you feel super woke
node.description: For many of us, the idea of spoiling those we care about in the wake of long lockdowns (and a very long year indeed) feels like the perfect solution to a rather torturous year.

node.title: Beth and Larry spent almost $700 on COVID-19 travel insurance. It won't cover them for lockdowns, border closures
node.description: Australians travelling overseas for the first time since international borders reopened are paying hundreds of dollars for travel insurance — but the fine print reveals some very big COVID-related exclusions.

node.title: Do you think there's a gender pay gap at your work? That info could one day be made public
node.description: More businesses may be forced to report things, such as whether they pay superannuation on parental leave, how much their chief executive is paid and provide a clearer breakdown of wages, if recommendations to a government review of the Workplace Gender Equality Act are taken up.

node.title: Not everyone singing from same hymn sheet over vaccinations mandate
node.description: People working in sectors that require a vaccine pass must have their first inoculation by Friday week, including religious leaders, hospitality and retail workers. Audio

node.title: Grammys Snubs and Surprises: Kacey Musgraves, Jon Batiste and Abba

node.title: ‘The Humans’ Review: Reasons (Not) to be Cheerful
node.description: Stephen Karam’s film adaptation of his powerful play acquires a supernatural sheen as a family gathers for Thanksgiving dinner.

node.title: America Has More Than One Spanglish
node.description: Our melting pot produces a delicious stew of languages.

node.title: A Texas court affirms a ruling against the governor’s ban on mask mandates.

node.title: Are airlines ready for the holiday crush?
node.description: By Sydney Ember and Niraj Chokshi

node.title: As virus cases rise in Europe, an economic toll returns.
node.description: By Patricia Cohen and Melissa Eddy

node.title: At least 210 coronavirus cases are linked to a South Korean religious settlement.
node.description: Nearly half of the residents at the facility in the city of Cheonan tested positive for Covid, an outbreak that comes as South Korea’s case levels surge.

node.title: Cyclist Sets Record 'Drawing' Mustached Man With GPS in Honor of 'Movember'
node.description: "There's always the potential for things to go wrong, and I get a great sense of satisfaction when the image appears as planned," Anthony Hoyte said.

node.title: Traders Unmoved By Biden Releasing Oil Barrels From Reserves, Stock Prices Rise
node.description: "The problem is that everybody knows that this measure is temporary," said one trading expert of the 2 percent stock increase.

node.title: Eric Holder Says Ohio's New Congressional Map 'An Insult' as Democrats Sue Over Boundaries
node.description: The plan is "even more rigged than its predecessor and an outlier among partisan gerrymanders nationwide," the lawsuit alleges.

node.title: Businesses failing to enforce pass requirements to face big fines
node.description: The government is releasing a new tool to help businesses assess whether they should be requiring workers to be vaccinated. Video

node.title: High price of gold sees surge to prospecting in West Coast
node.description: The West Coast of the South Island has seen a surge of interest from players large and small in gold prospecting.

node.title: College Football Games to Watch This Week
node.description: There are a handful of high-stakes games this week. Here are the rivalries we recommend watching.

node.title: Kellogg's Will Permanently Replace Some Striking Workers as Negotiations Break Down Again
node.description: Kellogg's workers have been hitting the picket lines since October 5 to demand changes to a wage system which results in lower pay for newer employees.

node.title: Man Wielding AK-47 Holds Little Caesars Pizza Employees at Gunpoint Over Wait Time
node.description: Charles Doty Jr. allegedly left to get the assault rifle after he was told it would take 10 minutes to cook his pizza.

node.title: Kevin Spacey Must Pay 'House of Cards' Studio $31M for Losses Brought On By His Firing
node.description: An arbitration panel said the actor must pay back production company MRC after he was fired and it had to completely restructure the sixth season.

node.title: Ex-Baltimore County cop sentenced to home detention for 2017 rape
node.description: Anthony Westerman, 27, was also convicted of second-degree assault for a 2019 incident.

node.title: Medical College Uses COVID Relief Funds to Give Each of Its Students $10,000 in Cash
node.description: Meharry Medical College President James Hildreth sent the school's students a video on Monday in which he said the money is theirs with no strings attached.

node.title: Pushing ahead with Marinus Link would result in 'Snowy 2.0' like loss, report finds
node.description: A proposed undersea power cable and electricity storage project in Tasmania would not be able to compete with cheaper battery storage in Victoria, a report has found.

node.title: SA's border is open. How are businesses responding?
node.description: With the border open, South Australian businesses are having to adapt quickly. Some are imposing their own vaccine mandates, while others are calling for more clarity.

node.title: 'I would be a statistic if it wasn't for football': First Indigenous Matilda Karen Menzies
node.description: Karen Menzies didn't know she was Indigenous until she was 16. As she struggled to come to terms with her identity, football provided her safety, purpose and joy. In many ways, it saved her life.

node.title: Meet the five women trying to unseat one of Australia's most popular politicians
node.description: Five women are vying to unseat Clover Moore, but all know it will take a miracle to beat the hugely popular Sydney Lord Mayor. This is why they're standing anyway.

node.title: Global hackers tried to break into Tasmania Police accounts 800 times
node.description: An internal report from Tasmania's Department of Police, Fire and Emergency Management has warned the agency is vulnerable to attack from cyber criminals without extra resourcing.

node.title: Royal Commissioner acknowledges potential conflict of interest over friendship with RSL president, who co-owned vineyard with brother
node.description: Royal commissioner James Douglas QC — whose brother once co-owned a vineyard with the president of the RSL — has acknowledged a potential conflict of interest just days out from the start of the royal commission into veteran suicides.

node.title: Could you really jump from a plane into a storm, holding 9 kilos of stolen cash, and survive?
node.description: For 50 years, DB Cooper has occupied a special place in American mythology: The well-dressed stranger who committed the perfect crime, fell from the sky and maybe, just maybe, got away with it.

node.title: Mystery surrounds the death of missing campers. Could police be close to finding the answers?
node.description: It's been a long 18 months for the family of Russell Hill and Carol Clay as they wait to find out exactly what happened out in the remote high country where they disappeared.

node.title: See the incredibly detailed data sparking allegations of 'widespread' illegal logging in Australian forests
node.description: High-resolution spatial data and information obtained as part of an ABC investigation sparks allegations of widespread and systemic illegal logging in protected Victorian water catchments.

node.title: Plea for way home for hundreds of Tongan seasonal workers
node.description: Hundreds of Tongan seasonal workers from the RSE scheme are stranded in New Zealand desperate to get home.

node.title: Proposals to price agricultural emissions a failure, say environmental groups
node.description: Environmental groups are calling on the government to shelve options for pricing agricultural greenhouse gas emissions proposed by the partnership of primary sector organisations.
